awd_titl_txt: Information Assurance Scholarships for Service (SfS) at the University of Nebraska at Omaha
awd_abstract_narration:
This project expands the ongoing CyberCorps®: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at the University of Nebraska at Omaha (UNO), building on its existing capabilities to address the national cyber security personnel crisis. In 2001, the University of Nebraska established the Nebraska Center for Information Assurance (NUCIA) at UNO and, in 2003, it was approved as a the Center of Academic Excellence in Information Assurance Education (CAEIAE) and received its first NSF award for SFS scholarships. Since 2003 UNO has produced numerous IA graduates, including 34 Scholarship for Service scholars.

The program is designed to present the students with a technical background including network security, reverse engineering, critical infrastructure protection, security theory, the foundations of Information Assurance, and other topics in cybersecurity. SFS students have demonstrated their technical proficiency by participating -- and scoring highly -- in international cyber competitions. Broader impacts of the student support include the students presenting briefings on critical infrastructure protection before Federal and other government officials. The SFS students also work with DoD to deliver cybersecurity training through worldwide workshops, and assist local industry in security auditing and training.

Upon graduation the UNO scholars have moved on to positions within NSF, Departments of Commerce and Treasury, and the United States Strategic Command, among others. Past SFS students regularly return to the institution and participate in the mentoring and competitions along with current SFS students, thus perpetuating the support as well as linking new UNO graduates with practitioners in the field. NUCIA continues to strengthen its partnerships with local community colleges and high schools to recruit talented students for the SFS program as well as promote awareness of information assurance as a career choice.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Since 2003, we have expanded our cyberecurity program in every dimension:  more students, degrees and certificates, research, and alumni to help new graduates.  The Scholarship for Service (SfS) program was a major catalyst for that success. The students in the SfS program are also expected to actively work on research projects, and the students have both published in journals and presented at conferences. The following publications highlight some of their work, and the student names are in bold face:

Grandgenett, R., Mahoney, W., R., Gandhi, (2015) “Authentication Bypass and Remote Escalated I/O Command Attacks”, 10th CISRC. Best paper award.

Hefley, Michael, Gabi Wethor, and Matthew L. Hale, (2017) “Multimodal Data Fusion and Behavioral Analysis Tooling for Exploring Trust, Trust-propensity, and Phishing Victimization in Online Environments,” 51st HICSS.

Hale, Matthew L., Ellis, D., Gamble, G., Walter, C., and Lin, J., (2015) “SecuWear: An open source, multi-component hardware/software platform for exploring wearable security,” 4th IEEE International Conference on Mobile Services.

Hale, Matthew L., and Hanson, S., (2015b) “A Testbed and Process for Analyzing Attack Vectors and Vulnerabilities in Hybrid Mobile Apps Connected to RESTful Web Services,” IEEE SERVICES Visionary Track, Security and Privacy Engineering.

Wertzberger, Nicholas, Glatter, C., Mahoney, W., Gandhi R., Dick, K., (2011) “Towards a Low-Cost SCADA Test Bed: An Open-Source Platform for Hardware-in-the-Loop Simulation”, STMACIP’11.

Intellectual merit highlights of our SfS grant include the participation in Locked Shields, a NATO cyber exercise with 550 people from 26 nations. Teams defend the network services of a fictional country, including Industrial Control Systems. A team of six UNO students put together the attack/defend scenarios for NATO for the exercise.

Chuck Hagel, former Secretary of Defense, visited UNO. Our SfS students described many of their research projects. Two SfS students received his advice on particular areas of interest within DoD. Mr. Hagle also encouraged students to further develop the NATO partnership and contribute to their efforts.

Broader Impacts

First, the primary impact we have thanks to the SfS program is the production of students who go on to the agencies that hire them. These agencies include Strategic Command, NSA, the Departments of Treasury, Commerce, the Army, Sandia Labs, Idaho Labs, Mitre, and others. We consistently receive favorable feedback from these agencies.

Second, UNO's cybersecurity programs have a long history and an increasingly upward growth trend. The following table illustrates the growth in the program over the past several years, which would not have been accomplished without the SfS program.

UNO IA/Cybersecurity Enrollment History

 

 

Our student club, NULLify, was created by SfS students and this November marks the fifth year of their High School cybersecurity event. An objective has been to increase the number of high school students exposed to our program.  The students actively participate in open-house recruiting events, demonstrate attacks, and answer questions. SfS students also participate in college sponsored high/middle school outreach events and assist with the GenCyber workshop.

Our SfS students actively participate in lectures/lab development for our introductory class. This class brings in students from a diverse set of academic backgrounds and majors, presenting information on personal privacy, email security, safe surfing, and other cybersecurity topics.

Another broad impact comes about through our undergraduate and graduate capstones. Local industry partners use teams of students to assess real-world systems. The students are given a software system, networking hardware, or similar and perform an assessment, including a detailed “customer” report. These classes are a key technology transfer component of the SfS program and are required.

Finally, some of the impact highlights of our SfS students include:

  • One graduate worked at NSA for 11 years and is also now one of our adjunct instructors.

  • Another is the youngest person hired as a Branch Chief for the Computer Network Defense branch, Strategic Command.

  • A graduate now at DISA meets personally with SfS students at the Job Fair every January to assist them ingovernment employment.

  • Another also meets us at the Fair and recruits additional SfS students to the area.

  • One graduate interned and was hired by Sandia. He has assisted with the hiring of three more students by Sandia.

  • SfS students repeatedly presented material at the International Cyber Defense Workshop, hosted by the Assistant Secretary of Defense.

  • One of our SfS students presented our research to past CIA director George Tenet.

  • SfS students provided many briefings for Nebraska Congressman Lee Terry, on the bipartisan Communications and Technology Cybersecurity Working Group.  Our students also provided cybersecurity briefings for the then new congressman, Mr. Brad Ashford.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2017
Modified by: William R Mahoney

Images (1 of )
  • SfS student Ryan Grandgenett presented his research paper, "Exploitation of Allen Bradley?s Implementation of EtherNet/IP for Denial of Service Against Industrial Control Systems? at ICCWS-2014. He is shown here with Dr. John McCarthy, Cranfield University, UK.
    William Mahoney
    Copyrighted
    William R Mahoney
    Ryan Grandgenett with John McCarthy
  • In 2016, six graduate students in Information Assurance helped the NATO Cooperative Cyber Defence Center of Excellence prepare for its Locked Shields exercise.
    William Mahoney
    Copyrighted
    William R Mahoney
    NATO Locked Shields
  • The 2015 High School Capture-the-Flag Competition was a success!
    William Mahoney
    Copyrighted
    William R Mahoney
    2015 CTF Competition
  • NULLify wion 1st Place in the CTF competition at the 2015 NATO Cyber Security Symposium (NIAS 2015) by solving all challenges in the competition within hours. NULLify participated remotely from Omaha, NE. In this photo, Dr. Hale points out NULLIfy's rank at the top of the leaderboard.
    Robin Gandhi
    Copyrighted
    William R Mahoney
    NATO Brussels
  • Dr. Robin Gandhi, along with SfS students Mike Manis and James Percival, discuss cybersecurity with former Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel
    UNO/Ryan
    William R Mahoney
    Chuck Hagel Visit
  • Dalton Ellis and Joanna Gardner brief US Representative Brad Ashford on student activities.
    UNO/Ryan Henriksen
    William R Mahoney
    Visit from US Representative Brad Ashford
